PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform honourable senators of the death at 11.10 p.m. last night of Senator Alice Olive Zakharov, who served Australia and Victoria with distinction in this place from 1 July 1982.

PARA.TAB: Senator Zakharov was a highly regarded and respected member of the Senate. She was an active member and chair of many Senate and joint committees. As an acting deputy president and temporary chairman of committees and as a long serving chair of the community affairs committees, she made a substantial contribution to the work of the Senate and its proceedings. I intend to speak to the condolence motion, but I now call on Senator Gareth Evans to move the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Monday, 6 March 1995, of Senator Alice Olive Zakharov, a senator for the state of Victoria from 1982, a former chair of a number of Senate committees and a temporary chairman of committees from 1987; places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night came the news we had all been fearing since we first heard of Olive's terrible accident three weeks ago and learned how serious it was. We have had a little time to adjust since then to the possibility of her death, but it has not made the reality any easier to bear.

PARA.TAB: Olive Zakharov was born on 19 March 1929 in Melbourne. She held an arts degree from Melbourne University and also gained professional qualifications in counselling, which skills she very effectively employed in her main career before politics as a teacher and student counsellor.

She grew up in the depression years and later experienced the enormous difficulties of being a single mother without the support mechanisms that are available to women today. She was willing to turn her hand to almost any job to support her family and did so. She was at various times a registered psychologist, pathology assistant, shop assistant, mail officer, waitress and fruit picker.

In these early years was no doubt born her absolutely determined and unswerving commitments to social justice, to socialism and to feminism with which all of us who knew her and worked with her were so familiar—the kinds of commitments that led, among other things, to her being recognised as Australian Humanist of the Year in 1984.

Olive came to this place in 1983 having already established a career and raised her family. She had been a longstanding member of the Australian Labor Party; she was an executive member of the Montmorency branch for nearly 20 years. In later years she threw her energies into party and community work in her new suburb of residence, Port Melbourne, as well as being throughout her Senate career an enormously active and dedicated server of rural Victoria. She travelled the length and breadth of the state—which senators are supposed to do but do not always do—showing a particular capacity to relate to the lives and work of ordinary country people.

We all know how many significant contributions Olive made to the work of this chamber, among other things, as a Temporary Chairman of Committees, as Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, and as a member of estimates committees and committees on community affairs, regulations and ordinances, senators' interests, ASIO, Joint House, national resources, environment and tourism, video materials and the human embryo experimentation bill.

Olive was undoubtedly best known publicly for her work on women's issues. Her earlier life and work experience as a part-time student and employee strengthened her understanding of women's role in society and made her absolutely determined to improve the status of women. A committed trade unionist and, as I have already said, feminist, Olive was involved in affirmative action policy development. She was one of the strongest early voices addressing sexual harassment issues. And she was particularly well known for her stand against domestic violence. The measure of her courage and personal strength in this respect was, I think, best demonstrated when in 1993 she spoke publicly, in an effort as always to help others, about the mental and physical abuse that she herself had suffered.

She was a strong supporter of the sex discrimination legislation for its protection of not only women but also gays and lesbians. A cause did not have to be easy or especially popular for it to command Olive's attention and commitment; that always came from the heart.

I think it is important to appreciate that, here as elsewhere, Olive's commitment was not just to issues in the abstract but to the people who were affected by them. She was fantastically supportive of people in distress and of individuals, organisations and community groups needing support and attention. I can say that with some personal conviction because Olive was very kind, thoughtful and helpful to a member of my own family a few years ago who, as a young teenage girl, was trying to work out what really mattered in life. She found a role model in Olive with a marvellous combination of idealism, compassion and practical humanism.

It is important to know about Olive—because it was so important to her—that while, as we all know, she was the quietest, most unaggressive and unflamboyant of people, she was ideologically, throughout her life, a very fierce socialist, starting her career in this respect, I have to say, considerably further to the left than the ALP! She was certainly a major participant and contributor to the peace movement, being a member of the Campaign for International Cooperation and Disarmament and World Women Parliamentarians for Peace.

Olive represented the Australian Peace Movement in 1988, for example, as a witness of the first destruction of a nuclear missile in the USSR under the START treaty. She was Australian delegate to the Vienna Peace Conference in 1987.

Not that all her involvement in these issues during the Cold War years brought her particularly closer to Russia. There is a delightful story about her being paged at Moscow airport on one delegation visit. When the announcer called for `Olive Zakharova', Olive didn't even begin to recognise the Russian female form of her name and missed the plane accordingly.

She did, however, come under notice, it has to be acknowledged, from the intelligence agencies. A few years ago she asked, when this became possible, to see her own ASIO files. She was extremely offended by two things in particular she found. First, her name had been sold to ASIO for an extremely small amount—her recollection was that it may have been just 2s 6d. Secondly, after some description of her husband, there was a comment in the files about Olive, that she `seems like a nice woman'. Olive was to her legion of friends and admirers throughout the country and certainly in this place more than just a `nice woman'.

We are not always completely honest on these occasions but I am being utterly honest when I say, at least on behalf of all her colleagues on this side of the chamber, that we not only respected and admired Olive Zakharov; we loved her. Mr President, on behalf of the government, I extend to Olive's family, her children, Robin, Jeannie and Martin Zakharov, and also her personal staff, who have been so close to her and who have also had to bear so much stress and pain in the last few weeks, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement. Their loss is all of ours and we are going to feel it for a long time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of coalition senators to support the motion of condolence upon the death of Olive Zakharov. This is a sad day for the Senate, and particularly for the family and friends of Olive. It is sometimes said that life as a backbench government member or senator is one that provides little opportunity to make a mark in public life. Equally, in an environment in which promotion is sometimes regarded as being dependent on toeing the line, the willingness of backbenchers to hold true to their beliefs and ideals, if that means advocating unpopular and unfashionable views, is at times under pressure.

PARA.TAB: Olive Zakharov, however, will be remembered in this place because she did make a mark and she did hold true to those principles, causes and beliefs that drew her towards political activism at an early age. That was because she was passionately motivated by her desire to see the elimination of what she regarded as the injustices and faults within our society. That passion was the result of a genuine sense of humanity. It was borne out of her own personal experiences—be it the deprivation that her family endured during the Great Depression, the discrimination she faced as a woman and a single parent or the natural desire of parents to see their children inherit a safe and peaceful world.

Despite the fact that Senator Zakharov came to this parliament relatively late in life, she had been a political activist for the majority of her life. Her time in the Melbourne University branch of the Communist Party during the early 1950s and the attention that that attracted—which was mentioned by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans)—are well known. A little later, she began her long association with the Australian Labor Party and, in particular, the Socialist Left of the Victorian branch of that party, an association which I understand lasted for over three decades.

In her maiden speech—as they were then known—Olive Zakharov spelt out her commitment to many of those issues which were to be at the centre of her contribution to the parliament during her time here: issues such as social justice, poverty, unemployment, discrimination and the world peace movement. Those issues were, of course, not new to her. In particular, Senator Zakharov had had a long-time involvement in the peace movement, both in relation to the Vietnam War and the broader issue of nuclear disarmament. That role was acknowledged in 1988 when she was invited as a representative of the Australian peace movement to witness the destruction of four Soviet SS22 missiles on the Kazakhstan steppes which commenced the Soviet Union's implementation of the START treaty. She was one of just 28 guests and the only foreign parliamentarian to attend. It was an occasion that she described in this chamber as `the chance of a thousand lifetimes'.

On the eve of International Women's Day, I also want to acknowledge her role as an advocate of women's rights. She fought with undoubted commitment against the type of discrimination she had personally endured. Needless to say, she was, as Senator Gareth Evans said, a supporter of the current government's anti-discrimination legislation, introduced in its first year of office. She also campaigned against domestic violence directly towards women. Her courage in revealing her own personal suffering in November 1993 was an example of that. Highlighting just two of these areas probably does not do justice to the broad range of issues that Olive Zakharov involved herself in. She was certainly not a single issues person.

I could mention her commitment to the cause of gay and lesbian rights and her tangible support for the fight against HIV and AIDS through her involvement in organisations such as the Victorian AIDS Council and the Victorian AIDS Trust. Equally, I could also mention her support for people with disabilities. In her first speech, Senator Zakharov used a quote from Hamlet to epitomise her personal philosophy. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: This above all: to thine own self be true, And it must follow, as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man
And, of course, she then added `woman'. She concluded that speech by saying:

. . . I state unequivocally that I am a socialist, a unionist and a feminist and that I intend to spend my term in office in the service of the people of Victoria, working towards a society where every individual can live with dignity and security.
I doubt whether there is anyone in this chamber that in the framework of her strong beliefs would argue that she failed to live up to those commitments.

PARA.TAB: In a personal sense, I will miss Olive Zakharov. I particularly admire politicians with a sense of cause. She was a very genuine and committed person yet, as the minister also said, always friendly and courteous. She touched many lives for the better, and she worked for the benefit of many that she would never meet, particularly the exploited and the disadvantaged. I am personally pleased to publicly have this opportunity to recognise her very significant contribution to our community and our society. On behalf of all opposition senators, I extend my sincere condolences to Senator Zakharov's three children, her family and her friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I rise to support the condolence motion for Senator Olive Zakharov. In this place and in this occupation, we get to know some of our colleagues better than others. In this place, such is the frailty of human existence, we get to speak fairly regularly on condolence motions. But I have not previously spoken to a condolence motion for a contemporary—for a woman I saw every sitting day, sitting over there not far from me. I did not know Olive Zakharov as well as I might have liked to, but her death has given me the opportunity to reflect on her speeches and to read about her life.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of my colleagues in the Democrats, I extend our sympathy to her family. To her children, her two daughters and her son, I can only say that her words and deeds are an admirable testimony to the woman who was their mother, and I hope they can take some comfort from this.

As was referred to by Senator Hill, Olive Zakharov in her first speech described herself as a socialist, a unionist and a feminist. She said that these descriptions of her were `unequivocal'—I think that is the Olive we know. I would add that Olive Zakharov seems to me to have been an idealist also, and an idealist in the best sense of the word. We would all recognise that maintaining idealism is a very difficult task in politics. Olive Zakharov was a believer in the worth of each man, woman and child on this earth. Working for a society in which respect and dignity for each human being are the norm was one of her most deeply held motivations, and her life's work exemplifies this commitment.

It is no wonder that Olive Zakharov was a strong unionist; she said that many of her childhood memories were of the Depression of the 1930s. She believed that it was only through the solidarity of the trade union movement that workers could attain safe working conditions and fair wages. She is also reported as saying that many politicians were out of touch with the real world.

I think it is easy to understand her frustration with the fact that so many Australians seem to believe that proper working conditions just eventuated from the goodness of employers' hearts. From her own experience, she knew better. As someone who had worked as a shop assistant, mail officer, waitress, fruit picker, and teacher, she knew, as she said, what it was like to be exploited—and doubly so as a female. I understand her interjections of disgust, which were audible to me in many a question time, at the underlying assumptions of the questioner. We all now know about Olive Zakharov's experience of domestic violence, and speaking out about it was a courageous act for a woman who was obviously inclined to be very private about her personal life.

There were other aspects to this modest woman's life, not the least of which was her commitment to the peace movement. To be the only Western politician invited to watch the destruction of some intermediate range missiles, under the agreement made between Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Regan in 1988, is a very special recognition of her work.
Mother, musician, bushwalker, peace activist and politician—on this, the eve of International Women's Day, I think it is true to say that Senator Olive Zakharov will be remembered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion for Senator Olive Zakharov, as moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). I know I speak for everyone here when I say how saddened I was to hear of her accident. Olive passed away last night, without regaining consciousness, and I would like to extend my deepest sympathy to her family and many friends—and particularly to members on the other side.

PARA.TAB: Olive entered this place as an ALP senator for Victoria in 1983. I remember her well because we both came into this place on the same day. In her first speech, Olive affirmed her commitment to securing social justice and equity for the powerless and disadvantaged in society—low paid textile workers, the aged, the disabled, the single parent families and their children—and she pursued this commitment vigorously during her 11 years as a senator. Education, health and welfare constituted her overriding interest, and she campaigned to improve the lot of women, single parents, Aboriginals and migrant families in these areas.

Olive was born in 1929 in Victoria. Her experience in growing up during the harsh Depression years were to shape her commitment to social justice for all Australians that was to remain forever with her. After leaving school she undertook many diverse jobs, including work as a fruit-picker, shop assistant, waitress and clerk. The experience she gained from working with a variety of people enabled her to be such an effective representative of the Victorian people when she entered federal politics later in her life. She returned to complete her education in the early 1960s, studying for an arts degree and other degrees. That was a great achievement considering she was also raising three children and working at weekends to pay for university fees.

After graduating, Olive Zakharov worked as a school counsellor until her election to the Senate in 1983. During her time here, Olive's great commitment was evident from her participation in the committee stage and chairing various committees. She served as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Natural Resources, which I remember well as I travelled around Australia with her as part of that committee. She also served as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs and then on the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. Olive also participated in the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and the contentious Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill. As well, Olive was an extremely hardworking member of estimates committees.

Throughout her time in the Senate Olive Zakharov maintained her great interest in education, welfare and health issues and was a tireless advocate for the underdog in the best Australian tradition. In recent years she spoke out against domestic violence, raising a serious social issue that many would rather leave unspoken and placing on the public record her own experiences of physical and mental abuse during her marriage. Due to great reserves of strength and fortitude, Olive left that abusive situation and brought up three children on her own. As a single parent of three, she experienced at first-hand the pressures and difficulties of raising a family single-handedly. It was these experiences that made her such a tireless advocate for women and children suffering in similar situations.

Olive Zakharov served the people of Victoria well for 12 years and I am sure would have served for many more years had this tragic accident not prematurely ended her life. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to Olive Zakharov's family, her two daughters and son, and also her many friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Margetts and on my own behalf, I rise in support of this condolence motion. Many in this chamber knew Olive Zakharov far better than we did and will undoubtedly miss her greatly. We can only echo the eloquent and heartfelt words already expressed. We share the respect and love in which she has been held by all who knew her, both in this parliament and in the community. She will live in people's memories as a champion of social justice, a women's advocate and a worker against discrimination of any kind.

PARA.TAB: I first came to know Olive Zakharov through the group Psychologists for the Prevention of War. I am sure members of that group would want to express their gratitude for her support and her friendship. It is only one example of the many areas in which she made such a valued contribution. Senator Margetts and I publicly express our thanks to Senator Olive Zakharov for her example of service, her loyalty to her values and her contribution to this parliament. We express deepest condolences to her family, her children, her colleagues and her friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to join with all colleagues in this condolence motion. This morning my car driver, when he was informed by me of Olive's passing, said almost the very same thing as the ASIO agent—that she appears to be a nice woman—except my car driver did not use the word `appears'. He said quite categorically, `She was a nice woman.' Of course, she was more than that, as has been so eloquently expressed around the chamber today. There is not a great deal more I could add to that.

PARA.TAB: I served with Olive Zakharov on a number of committees, as many of you did as well. Some of the contentious committees, as Senator Boswell said, were the Select Committee on Video Material and the Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill. There were clearly differences of view expressed, but at least one thing about Olive that is not necessarily displayed by members of parliament is that you always knew where she stood. I think everybody around this chamber would appreciate what I am saying: you always knew where she stood.

You could have a discussion with her about particular matters and you could hear the questioning that was developed by her in particular committees. Though there were differences of opinion, one always knew that there was a similar objective to be achieved—the objective of trying to achieve a societal response to the imperative that every individual human being has an inherent dignity. From where that inherent dignity is derived is another question—a deep question which a speaker would not be able to discuss in the time available. Social justice was an issue which I know concerned her all her life. In the area of industrial relations, I suppose it concerned her as much as it concerns me even at this time. But more of that later; this is not the time to canvass those particular matters.

Why is it that senators do not depart this place by dying of natural causes or from old age? I think since I have been here there have been three sitting senators—somebody can correct me if I am wrong—for whom there have been condolence motions moved. There was Ivor Greenwood, who died suddenly of a heart attack. There was John Knight, who also died suddenly of a heart attack. There was Alan Missen, who was sitting at the same time, and Olive. It is an added feeling of loss, I suppose, when you consider that Olive was going to retire. This was her last term, as I understand it. She was a great seeker after peace—peace for the whole of the world. She was a great seeker after changing societal structures which exploited people, and that is very important. Ultimately, with those societal structures having been changed, you need an added emphasis, and that is inner healing.

I pray that Olive has now found peace. I also join my colleagues in expressing my deepest sympathy to Olive's daughters and son and also to Olive's staff, who were extremely loyal to her and had every reason to be, because she was extremely loyal and generous to them. I am sure they would not mind my saying that now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to support this condolence motion and pay tribute to the life and work of Olive Zakharov. I knew Olive through my work in the Labor Party in Victoria. Her term as a senator coincided largely with the term in which I was secretary of the Victorian Socialist Left, so my relations with and views of Olive were developed in that context.

PARA.TAB: Olive's untimely and tragic death has taken from us a great comrade and colleague. My experience is, as has been stated here, that Olive was indeed an unflinching socialist, a unionist and a feminist. She was indeed a very proud member of the Socialist Left and she had a lifelong commitment to building a better Australian society through the Australian Labor movement.

Olive embodied the great traditions of socialist humanism in this country. She was born at the outbreak of the Depression and she saw through that experience the inherent wrongs of capitalism that, in her view, gave rise to deep poverty and, of course, to fascism in the 1930s, a world war, and other conflicts throughout recent decades. That experience instilled in her a lifelong commitment to peace, social justice and civil liberties.

Olive epitomised the experience of a generation of Australian socialists. Her parents passed on to her, as she passed on to her children, a deep commitment to social change and human dignity. She explained that her most vivid memories of the 1930s were that of men coming to the door for food and money, of the humiliation of poverty and the indignity that stems from inequality. She said that her memories of the talk of home were of fascism in Italy and Germany and the struggles in the Spanish Civil War. Of course, these experiences helped shape in her a commitment to peace and social justice which eventually led to her coming here to this chamber.

Olive probably did join the Communist Party in the 1940s. She was driven by a sense of idealism and a hatred of inequality. She studied at the Marx school in Melbourne in 1946 and 1947. She is remembered fondly by the comrades of that period, who talk of her selfless and honest approach and her direct approach to political struggle.

It was her work in the Communist Party which brought her into conflict with the security forces and secret police of this country, a struggle which of course was played out finally through her work in the parliamentary committee that was supposed to be supervising ASIO. That struggle with ASIO had arisen over the issue of the release of Olive's file, which Senator Gareth Evans has already referred to. If I recall correctly, the issue at the time was that ASIO was most concerned about the 30-year rule for the relief of archival material and wanted it extended to 50 years. ASIO had argued that its files were incomplete and that any release of information might identify agents who had provided original material.

Olive said that the release of her own file was in itself a revelation because it contained only a fraction of the material actually held by ASIO and the information disclosed was inaccurate and the bulk of the material inconsequential. The very thought of ASIO chasing fine and, I think, peace loving people like Olive Zakharov to me highlights just how ludicrous the whole operations of the Cold War were in Australia and, of course, her experiences really do demonstrate that to me.

Olive's world view was shaped by experiences of her younger years, but they did not remain fixed. Her views grew out of her experiences of life and society and, as they changed, so did her views. She commenced her teaching training in the 1950s and, like many women of that period, had to leave it as she devoted her primary energies to raising her three children—Robin, Martin and Jeannie. She completed her degree as a mature age student. She was a teacher, a psychologist and a student counsellor. She taught at Montmorency High School. She maintained a lifelong interest in education, seeing education as an important vehicle for the achievement of personal emancipation and the development of a comprehensive, coherent state education system as being fundamental to a just society.

She fought in the battles of the 1970s against conservative state governments to build decent state education in Victoria. Of course, she was horrified by the destruction wrought by the current Victorian state government, which has done so much to reverse the achievements of teachers of Olive's generation.

Olive's humanist philosophy found outlet in a range of other issues. She was particularly active in the area of AIDS education and an early advocate of the acceptance on equitable terms of gays and lesbians in Australian society. Olive campaigned internationally for the recognition of AIDS awareness. She took a leading role in campaigning within the Australian government at the time when this issue was far less understood than it is today. Her last public function as a senator was to attend the mid-summer festival launch of the ALP's gay and lesbian network. Her interest in human relations issues goes back to the days when she was a teacher and, as a pioneer, she was instrumental in developing a human relations curriculum. Olive was very much ahead of her time on these and many other issues.

Olive also had a keen commitment to the arts. Her son Martin is a jazz musician, which meant that Olive had a particular interest in his work. But she was just as happy listening to the MSO. Olive was interested in all aspects of the arts, which was consistent with her humanist outlook.

She was a committed environmentalist and was particularly proud of her Senate work on the Antarctic and Kakadu. Her concerns for environmental issues, however, included a commitment to fighting for decent public housing and urban planning. She was an opponent of developments that undermine a community's sense of its own identity and of its history and, as a consequence, fought against such proposals as the bayside development in her suburb of Port Melbourne.

Her concern for the social environment extended beyond education to the development of proper public health and aged-care accommodation. She had a view of law reform and censorship which saw the state as an instrument for the emancipation of humanity when harnessed to a respect for individual rights and human dignity. Public institutions, in Olive's view, should be geared towards alleviating social injustice, and her latest work on prison education is one example of her maintenance to that commitment.

Olive was a feminist and a campaigner for full equality of women through the proper participation of women in all aspects of social organisations, particularly their political processes. As the only female Labor federal member of parliament from Victoria, she was rightly proud of her contribution. However, Olive did not see feminism in a one-dimensional light; she saw throughout her life the fundamental importance of class in dividing our society and perpetuating inequality.

Olive's political career in the Labor Party was an extensive one. She was the backbone for many years of the Victorian Labor Party's health and welfare policy committee, and she helped develop Labor's views on many areas of health policy, particularly those relating to women's health. She was a delegate to the Victorian state ALP conference between 1972 and 1985. She was a member of the Montmorency branch of the Labor Party and an executive member between 1973 and 1983. She was an executive member of the old Diamond Valley FEA throughout the 1970s, and she secured a preselection for the Senate in 1982.

I can well recall the night of the Socialist Left executive meeting at which she did secure the recommendation. While I will not mention the name of her rival, I do recall the incident very well. It was suggested to us that it would be appropriate that Olive would probably serve the party better in the Senate, and her rival who put this case would probably best serve the party in the House of Representatives. I think Olive was particularly pleased to point out to me only last year how delightfully ironic it was that she went on to serve 12 years and the proponent of this proposal served 18 months.

As a senator, Olive sought to reach out to her community and her constituents. She remained an active advocate for trade union rights and for community participation. She took special pride in her work with rural communities, particularly in the Mallee, where she sought to provide a service to country women.

Olive's view of society and politics reflected the experiences of a generation and were shared by many hundreds of thousands of Australian activists of her generation. Her experiences and the lessons she drew from them had a common meaning that was shared by socialists within the Labor Party. I think a good summary of Olive's qualities and commitments can be found in a quote from another former member of the Communist Party of Australia, Jack Mundey, whose views I think Olive might have shared. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ecologists with a socialist perspective and socialists with an ecological perspective must form a coalition to tackle the wide ranging problems relating to human survival. Such survival is based on a way of living in harmony with the rest of nature. My dream and that of hundreds of thousands or millions might then come true—a socialist world with a human face, an ecological heart and egalitarian body.
I believe Olive shared that dream. We will miss her inspiration in working towards those goals. I extend my condolences to her family and staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we rise to express our sadness at the passing of one of our number and loved senator, Olive Zakharov. It is moving for her closest friends, representative of us all, to see the splendid array of single red roses that have been placed on her desk in the Senate. We are also proud of her qualities that have been expressed very eloquently by all those who have spoken in this condolence debate, especially the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot), the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Boswell) and representatives of independent senators.

PARA.TAB: I served with Olive Zakharov on the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. She was once chairman of that committee. She came with all her experience and qualities that have remarked upon. Her commitment to education was a very deep one. I also served on the parliament's monitoring committee of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

I genuinely note the references to her personal life story, particularly during the Depression, the 1940s: she studied at Melbourne University; she was a single mother; she cared for her children; she was a psychologist; she was a counsellor; and she was a senator for the last 12 years. Like many senators, when I first heard the news of the accident on St Kilda Road—it seems a few days ago—I was alarmed. Within the first 24 hours there was a hope that the injuries were not as serious as they turned out to be. We then learned as the days passed that there were very serious injuries and her concussion remained with her until she died.

I join with all senators in expressing sympathy to her children, her family and her friends. We always knew her as a member of the Socialist Left of the Labor Party. We always knew her as a Victorian. We always knew her as a woman. We knew her as a person of compassion and were moved by her as a person.

I will conclude by referring to a coincidence. Another Labor senator died 74 years before Olive as a result of an accident in a Melbourne street. It happened that Robert Guthrie, who was a senator for 18 years and was first elected to the Senate in 1903, a member of the Legislative Council of South Australia for 10 years, a member of the Seamen's Union and a main mover of the seamen's strike of 1890, was also involved in an accident on the corner of Swanston Street and Collins Street. He suffered concussion, never regained consciousness and died.

There was a similar condolence debate in the Senate, the sitting of which was then convened in the city of Melbourne where Mr Guthrie, as a South Australian, came to represent my state. I note the coincidence of these two incidents. It was mentioned in an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 21 January 1921. I extend my sympathies to Olive Zakharov's family and all her friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —Olive Zakharov will understand why I am not speaking at any great length in this condolence debate and she will excuse me for leaving the debate before it concludes. I want to associate myself with the remarks that my colleagues from all sides of the chamber have made about Olive, particularly those remarks that we will miss her. I particularly will miss her in the senators' alcove where on so many occasions we waited together for you, Mr President, and your predecessors to finish the prayers before we entered the chamber. Olive will appreciate my gesture: the red rose that I placed upon her desk was not placed there until you had concluded the prayers.

PARA.TAB: I extend my deepest condolence and that of my family to Olive's family and particularly to her staff, who were almost members of her family. Those condolences are extended to the many friends that she has throughout Victoria and throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the words that have been expressed by my colleagues on both sides of the chamber on this very sad day. Olive Zakharov was a person whom I, as a fellow Victorian, had come to like very much. She was a person who took a little bit of getting to know, but once you did she was a very nice and fine person.

PARA.TAB: Others have said most of the things that I wanted to say. But I did want to say publicly how much we are going to miss her. I want to thank her for her contribution, particularly to the labour movement and to the many things dear to members opposite, throughout her whole life which she had dedicated to many very important causes as she saw them. I wish to place that on record and to say that we are going to miss Olive Zakharov very much. It is a tragedy that she has left us in such very sad circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this condolence motion for my friend and colleague Olive Zakharov, I would like to endorse all the contributions that have been made in recognition of Olive which have paid tribute to her hard work, dedication to social justice and commitment to raising the status of women. I would particularly like to convey my sympathy to her family and staff.

PARA.TAB: Olive was a founding member of the government's status of women committee and worked with Pat Giles, its first chair, to institute a full caucus committee which monitored the work of ministers in those early days in the life of the Labor government. In 1983, the thought of having a status of women policy committee that actually influenced ministers, not to mention their departments, was something about which Olive felt very strongly. I remember well the way she spoke at those meetings when somewhat bewildered members of the bureaucracy would come forward to be questioned by Olive about their commitment to social justice and reforms for Australian women. We take it for granted today, but at that time it was very new and very revolutionary. I might say that it was somewhat reluctantly accepted in certain quarters at that time.

At that time, development of women's policy was not fully recognised in all sectors of the bureaucracy or in the parliament. Olive was vocal in insisting that ministers and departments adopt a women's agenda which reflected recognition of the need for major social reform to start redressing the inequity between women and men. So many of the achievements that we will be marking tomorrow on International Women's Day—20 years since International Women's Year 1975—can directly be traced to the work of Olive Zakharov. She has been a pioneer in her work in this regard.

One special occasion that I am sure she would want me to share with you was the time we finally persuaded members of the defence department to appear before the caucus status of women committee to answer questions about how they were changing their attitudes to women. If you can imagine all the pomp and splendour of senior defence department officials being questioned in that committee in 1983 by Olive Zakharov, who was so totally committed to the peace movement, you will know why I wanted to share that with you today.

Olive brought many qualities to the parliament. Perhaps her most significant characteristic was that she brought to all areas of her work the views and experiences of ordinary Australians. She never changed in this place. Some people do change as a result of this rarefied atmosphere—the time spent away from the constituency, the nature of the work and the pressures. Olive was not at all one of those who changed. She was always totally unassuming and modest in all she did, but she always reminded us very forcefully if at any time the views of ordinary men and women were not being considered.

She remained loyal to the people she knew so well from her extensive community work and former career as a teacher, student counsellor, and psychologist. She was, in her own words, `a socialist, a unionist and a feminist'. She was also a humanist and very much an idealist. Perhaps it was these aspects of her experience and ideology that enabled her to serve so effectively on the many caucus, Senate, and community committees.

She was especially dedicated to education and social justice and gave emphasis to people with special needs, including the unemployed, disabled, migrants and Aborigines. As all honourable senators know from her work both in this chamber and around the building on the many committees, Olive was always first to the meetings, always on time, always serving on more committees than some of us and always giving that total commitment.

I think she would not mind my saying that there was only one occasion on which she missed a division. That happened when the women's peace camp was on the lawns outside Old Parliament House in the mid-1980s. Olive, along with two others, Pat Giles and me, was visiting the women's peace camp, and I am afraid we had not checked with the whip. In those days there was not the same closeness of numbers; nevertheless, we were very contrite. I remember Olive saying that, if she had to miss a division once in her career, she was pleased that it was for the women's peace camp.

In conclusion, Olive would recognise the red roses on her desk not as mere floral tributes from her Senate colleagues but as socialist roses, very special roses—the international symbol of the socialist movement, and very much as a reflection of her fundamental philosophy of commitment to social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this condolence motion. I served with Senator Zakharov on the employment, education and training committee for four years. Since the restructuring of that committee, we have served as chair and deputy chair to each other, so we have had a very long and close association on many references and hearings right around the country.

PARA.TAB: I remember very clearly my first meeting with Olive Zakharov. It was on about my third day in this place when I had turned up to my first committee meeting. In these events, I usually tend to sit back, keep quiet and watch. But I was exposed to Olive's views on education in that committee, and I could not help myself. I found I had to speak up. On many occasions we very much disagreed on particular matters of education. It is a great tribute to Olive and the way in which she was prepared to negotiate things through that most of our reports—virtually all of them—over the last four years have been bipartisan in nature.

Senator Zakharov had been involved in education for a very long time, as was pointed out earlier by other speakers. She had retained a very passionate concern for what goes on in the schools and universities of this nation. She was a pioneer in establishing counselling services in our schools. She always reminded us that students should be the focus of our concerns when we deal with educational matters.

I remember that she had a number of very strong views about certain university vice-chancellors. She disliked pomp and circumstance in all its guises, as Senator Reynolds has already pointed out. She was not afraid to give a piece of her mind to university administrators who she felt were more concerned about status than students.

Senator Zakharov had very good community networks. These were very useful in our inquiries, particularly the first one I was involved in, which was the report on adult and community education. We rather daringly called it Come in Cinderella, and it is now a university textbook around Australia. We also had other landmark reports, like our one on youth unemployment called Wanted: Our future. I remember the very long hours the committee spent in coming up with unanimous recommendations in the shadow of the 1993 election. It was no mean feat.

This year, the committee is considering, amongst four other references, education and training in correctional facilities. Olive was very much a driving force behind the establishment of this inquiry. We will certainly miss her commitment and knowledge very much.

She had already carried out some very useful work in this area when she was overseas this year. She gave some excellent foundation material to the secretariat. We have not yet even called for any witnesses on this inquiry, which is not due to start until about June this year. It was typical of Olive that she was busy behind the scenes working to support an issue which she saw as being extremely important.

Senator Zakharov has also helped with a number of other inquiries in the Senate. Her work in them has been tireless. She was certainly the most regular attendee at all our private meetings. She was always at the interstate hearings. She was keen to talk to witnesses during coffee breaks. She would spend her own time in the promotion of the committee's work when she was out and about on other official duties.

When we travelled to interstate hearings, I knew that Olive spent a lot of time in airport lounges, Commonwealth cars and budget hotels with members of the committee secretariat discussing various issues not only related to education but which were of passionate concern to her. The secretariat also shares with us the very great sense of loss in Olive's passing.

As committee chair, I found Olive's ruling to be always fair. She pulled me up on many occasions. She was flexible in allowing the committee to collectively manage the inquiries it undertook under her chairmanship.

The year 1995 will be a very hectic one for the Employment, Education and Training References Committee. It will probably be our heaviest workload ever with five inquiries in hand. We will certainly miss Olive's energy and commitment. We are pleased that Senator Denman has now joined us. We are sure that she will very soon get caught up in the issues of employment, education and training in the way that Olive Zakharov did. We are very pleased to have her on board.

Olive's life was devoted to enhancing the life opportunities of all Australians, particularly those in our community who have been neglected or dispossessed or who lack the support and financial resources that we all take for granted as citizens of this country. I am sure that the employment, education and training work will continue to honour her memory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not fair that we have lost Olive Zakharov. It is not fair to her family. I know how proud she was of them all. It is not fair to her staff, to whom she was so close. I guess it is particularly not fair to the causes she championed.

PARA.TAB: There is, of course, not time to retail all the policy areas in which she was interested. Some of those have already been touched on. But from world peace to Antarctica, from family planning to anti-censorship, she was involved in them, as she was locally, as has also been mentioned, in her own suburb of Port Melbourne.

I guess I would hope that, somehow or other, to her memory the roof of her house could be retained. If you ever come off the ferry from Tasmania at Station Pier and look across towards the area where there is housing, you will see a house with a sign in big letters on the roof saying `not for sale', which was part of the campaign in opposition to the redevelopment of that area near Station Pier and the Missions to Seamen building, which she was campaigning to retain. I guess it is also an indication of her firm commitment to causes that she would go to the trouble of having a big sign like that painted on her roof to make so clear her position.

She was, as has been said, a proud member of the left—a solid and strong member of the left. As people would probably realise, I have taken Olive's accident and now her death hard. It has, I must say, helped my grieving a little to hear so many people speak so highly of her including, to some surprise, so many members of the House of Representatives. I was watching the condolence debate in there from 12.30, which was still going at 2 o'clock when we assembled here. I was pleased to hear so many members there express their appreciation of her. I had always thought she was underappreciated.

Olive was absolutely reliable. She took all her duties seriously. She time and again took on more than her share of tasks. She was absolutely assiduous in her work and an example to us all. Amongst the many things she and I had in common was, usually anyway, being on time for meetings except, as was alluded to a minute ago, for the Senate. We usually avoided prayers together. I must say that she probably would not have wanted the Senate to adjourn today on her account. I know that traditions mean we must, but I do not think she took the step that I took some years ago of lodging a letter with the clerk to the effect that if I happen to die in office I just want you to get on with the work.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will, John.

—Thank you. There are so many ways in which Olive and I were on the same wavelength and it is difficult to believe that she will not be back. I guess what I will miss most is being able to mutter under my breath—I hope mostly under my breath—during question time or during a caucus meeting about some objectionable performance in here or about some government decision or process with which we both disagreed. I think it will take a long time for me to stop thinking, as I do every day, `I must mention such and such to Olive when I see her next.' I guess in her memory, now that she is dead, when those of us who remain finish our weeping we will all have to struggle more to make up for her absence from the struggle.

PARA.TAB: It has been a privilege to have known Olive Zakharov, whose death leaves a big gap in my life and that of my family. Ros and Peter are both extremely sad about losing Olive, and we all send our condolences to her family, staff and friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in support of the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). I had the honour of serving on three committees with Senator Zakharov—community affairs, joint house and Senate estimates. As has been said so often already, Olive was an avid left winger and former communist and naturally enough had pretty strong views. Many of those views did not necessarily coincide with mine.

PARA.TAB: But one of the things I respected Olive for was the fact that she did hold very strong views and that she respected my right to hold my views. I think that is particularly important if we are all going to get on in this world, in this life and in this parliament, because what people do not see on the outside of this building is the work that is done in the committees and the cooperation that is forged in that committee work in trying to reach sensible solutions to the benefit of Australians right throughout this country. Olive did that with great dedication.

I found her an exceptionally hard worker on all those committees, as Senator Tierney, from his relatively brief experience with Olive, very eloquently stated. She was a member of a number of committees in which I participated but she was also chairman of the community affairs committee. Once again, I might not have always agreed with Olive but I could never say that I did not respect her, her knowledge of standing orders, her knowledge of Senate practice, her intelligence, her capabilities and, above all else, her fairness. She was very diligent, I have to say, in protecting her government regardless of whether we thought the government needed protecting.

I have always been able to say that Olive was a lovely lady. While I have said to a lot of people in the times that we have been interstate on committees and so forth that Olive's philosophy and mine certainly did not necessarily meet eye to eye too often, I was always able to respect her as a lovely lady. There are many people in this building who respected her, whether they be the workers in the dining room or those in the kitchens.

When we were on the joint house committee leading up to the opening of the new Parliament House she could empathise with many of the workers. As Senator Gareth Evans said, she was very proud of the fact that during her time she had been a waitress and she understood the difficulties that were going to be experienced by many of the waitresses in the dining room who were going to have to carry heavy trays up and down the stairs. I do not mind saying that very few of us on the joint house committee at that time even considered or contemplated that and obviously nor did the builders. I think she brought a dimension to this place that many of us really had to open our eyes to.

Many people respected her, whether it was those people in the kitchens or it was someone like Anne Lynch, the deputy clerk, who is in the Senate today and who always admired and respected Olive's dedication and her work effort and was never afraid to say so. I think that, too, is a significant point that should not be overlooked in this testimony to Olive.

She was always able to take a joke. I appreciated that on the committees because it certainly made some of those committees a lot easier to take. But I think the overwhelming thing is that Olive served the state of Victoria, her country and her Labor Party exceptionally well and will be remembered for a very long time as a consequence. I take this opportunity to extend my sincere sympathies to her family, her friends and all her colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to be involved in this condolence motion for Olive Zakharov and her family. I have not been impressed over the years by how often, just about every week, there is an article in the media that denigrates members of parliament. It has got to the stage where occasionally I think I should do something, that I should defend members of parliament; but, of course, in a democratic society it is very important that people can criticise their parliamentarians.

PARA.TAB: What has been said today highlights for me that here is one person's life as a senator that could be held up to the whole community as showing just what is done by a member of parliament—in this case, a close friend of mine and a person whom I think has proved an effective senator in this place. In her first speech, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been elected to the Senate at a time when the irrationalities of capitalism have inflicted increasing suffering and humiliation on very large numbers of our fellow Australians and most particularly on the weakest—workers unprotected by trade unions, the aged, the disabled, children and adolescents—

I think we have heard today—and we all knew it, of course—that Olive successfully discharged her mandate to work tirelessly to change the country and other things in her period in this Senate. In that, she is a model for so many other people because, when she first came into this chamber, there were within the Labor Party just a few women who were the models for others to follow. Now, throughout the Labor Party, young women take up that torch and have been inspired by that model of quiet efficiency that Olive represented.

PARA.TAB: Olive's political life was devoted to the Left cause. As one who shares that perspective, I feel it is important to emphasise that she made a contribution to the creation of views—on the left side of politics and in the parliament generally. For that, I would like to acknowledge her very important role, because ideas are the important thing. Often the ideas quietly expressed are just as powerful as some of the words expressed in this chamber that are full of cliches and not much else. Olive was a person who thought through the problems and attempted to get solutions.

In every way, she epitomised service to the Labor movement. She worked for a society of equals—equal respect for all people and equality in control of their lives with equal access to resources. In the past, the Labor movement often focused on class inequality while, at the same time, overlooking other types of inequality. Olive fought inequality wherever she saw it; social inequality between women and men was of particular concern to her. She was a visionary and an active feminist who saw that gender inequality disadvantaged both women and society, because society missed out on the valuable talents of women. I was prompted by Olive, Pat Giles and Margaret Reynolds over many years on those issues in such a way as to ensure that I, along with those of us who are male, was not able to lose the scales that often prevent us from seeing the obvious importance of them as major political issues.

Olive has played a role in transforming the ideas of so many of us that perhaps not everybody will understand. Of course, that goes for so many other issues, because what she really sought to do was to calmly and gently bring people to understand the issues of inequality and awaken in them the desire to change things.

She did not believe that caring was women's work and had no place in government, and that is a unique contribution that is very easily not acknowledged enough. I suppose it is only in more recent times that this is becoming a conventional wisdom. In the early years of our government, her persistence in that issue was most vital.

The other thing that always struck me about Olive is that her experience as a psychologist enabled her to bring out the best in those around her; it even allowed her to deal with some of the more difficult personalities in this chamber and this parliament. Thinking about that, I certainly appreciate that she often was very perceptive about the foibles and weaknesses of some of us, but she always played a positive role in dealing with those matters.

I will refer just briefly to what I think was a characteristic of her work, which I commend to everybody—and it might be seen to be a bit of a left perspective: she would participate in a mass movement of people and then come into the chamber and participate in the parliament. She, as much as anybody I know, carefully moulded that activity in the community yet at the same time participated in the highest levels of government discussion. That participation in the movements of people in this country, as has been mentioned, was very significant in the peace movement. I have been associated with her in that peace movement, and some of the things that have happened are the direct result of that contribution she made. Many people are now in the situation of benefiting from those activities that she undertook over many years in small groups of people, rallying people to the attainment of world peace and disarmament.

I conclude by referring to the fact that, just at a personal level, in this sort of left corner of the chamber, we will miss her very greatly. I do not know how we ever will be able to overcome the loss of friendship and comradeship that we had with Olive. I can only pass on my condolences and join with others in passing those condolences to her children.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I came into this chamber in 1987, Olive Zakharov was then the only federal female member of parliament for Victoria; and she and I became the only two female senators for Victoria, until Judith Troeth joined us in 1993. From 1987 to 1990, we were the only two female federal members—senators or members—representing Victoria. That meant that Olive and I found ourselves speaking at a large number of functions, a large number of nursing home openings and a large number of public meetings, on a platform together.

PARA.TAB: One of the things I always found with Olive was that, even though we were miles apart politically, we shared a mutual respect for each other. Whenever she was forced into the situation of defending a position in public in Victoria, she argued her point on the issues and never personalised the debate. But, when it was appropriate for us to cooperate—and there were such times—there were occasions when Olive and I could take off our political hats and put on our parliamentary hats.

I will give you one example of that. Because Olive and I shared a professional affiliation, both being psychologists and members of the Australian Psychological Society, at one stage we were invited to speak at an APS meeting. We were asked to speak on parliament, the role of parliament and the way in which professional organisations could make their representations to parliament and participate in legislation and the formation of legislation. Olive rang my Melbourne office and said to me, `Is there some way we can have a discussion beforehand so you can cover some issues and I can cover the others?' So Olive and I discussed what she would cover and what I would cover. I think some of our professional colleagues, both psychological and political, may be surprised that such cooperation was possible. Possible it was and effective it also was.

It was as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances that I also saw Olive's ability to put principle above party, an attribute which is vital for members of that committee to ensure that the rights of individuals are not infringed. Olive often took a line that was not always popular with her ministers and/or the bureaucracy. But I feel that the achievements of that committee are due to its members, as I said, putting principles, and the principles of that committee, first.

I also know how strongly Olive felt, as others have said, about many issues which have been mentioned in the chamber today. More than once I would look up when Olive was in the chair as Acting Deputy President to find her nodding when I was speaking on issues of privacy, about people with disabilities or on aged care. After she had been nodding vigorously one day which was not long before a preselection of mine, I said to her quietly outside, `Olive, please don't nod so vigorously because if word of that gets around my preselection might be threatened.' Whenever I looked up after that and Olive was tempted to nod, we would have a little smile between us and I knew that meant she was really nodding.

As we were sitting in airport lounges or swinging, as we did on one occasion, in hammock-type seats on an air force aircraft going back to Melbourne during a strike often we would find ourselves talking to each other, and Olive talked about her family. She often talked about her children and her grandchild. It was obvious she was very proud of their achievements.

She also had a great affinity with her staff. We will remember how strongly she felt about one of her staff who had a child. That staff member would often bring her child up to Canberra. You would often see Olive getting off a plane with prams, strollers, car seats and all sorts of things in order for her staff member to be able to continue working for her even though she had a small child. So Olive put into practice what she believed. I join with my colleagues in conveying my sincere condolences to her family, in particular her daughters and her son, and also to her staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution in joining in the words already said on behalf of Olive Zakharov. I will not canvass what has already been canvassed except to agree particularly with the contributions by some of my colleagues on this side. Margaret Reynolds reminded me of the many times that she, other Labor colleagues in this place and I have had the benefit of Olive's wisdom.

PARA.TAB: I want to say a couple of things about Olive. I think she had the balance in a special way between passionate commitment and tolerance. Indeed, I think not many of us get it right and certainly we do not get it right the way Olive did—that is, no matter how passionately she felt, and she was passionately committed to those issues that have already been mentioned, that never stopped her tolerating, really tolerating, people who held a different view. I guess there were some times when I wished people had paid Olive the same tolerance that she paid them. I think it was that balance of her passionate commitment and tolerance that was one of the many things that I will hold dear about her and in particular that I learned from her. I am not sure I have mastered it in the way that she had, but it is something that she taught me.

Olive also had a great sense of humour. Sometimes her sense of humour was not recorded, or at least not by name. I particularly recall the sex discrimination debates which took place in this chamber where the opposition made some of the most ridiculous contributions to public debate ever on record. The Hansard records `Government senators interjecting and laughing'. I would love you to know that among those government senators were Olive, Margaret, Pat Giles and me. But it was particularly Olive who sat through hours of that debate and laughed, as we all had to, at the folly at that time of the opposition.

Olive had also mastered that lovely line `Don't be too polite, girls'. The balance about it was that she was mannerly in dealing with people but absolutely clear about not being too polite when it came to saying her view about issues and campaigning for them.

Bruce Childs has also made a marvellous contribution today in saying that, when you read about parliamentarians who are worthy of scathing criticism, somebody like Olive has been overlooked. Many others could also be mentioned, but today we are talking about Olive. Bruce Childs's comments about that are something about which I will also be able to remind anybody who is critical of parliamentarians. It is an excellent point. In summary, Olive Zakharov was an excellent example of a fine parliamentarian and a splendid example of why women should be in parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to pay tribute to Senator Zakharov. I first met Senator Zakharov as a candidate in the 1993 election, which senators will remember was fought with a degree of acrimony on both sides. I was to meet Olive for a community radio debate on the issues of the campaign. As a candidate, I will admit that I was perhaps not looking forward to this encounter. However, as has been previously canvassed, Olive was a person who concentrated on issues rather than personalities. To my relief, but also to my pleasure in fighting an intellectual debate, we were able to have a reasoned debate of the issues on air and that was something for which I was grateful.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to record my memory of her as a passionate fighter for the cause of women—if not for affirmative action, then certainly for equal opportunity. That is something I feel she always made a point of arguing very well. I would also like to record the way in which her memory should be reviewed in country Victoria. I am also from country Victoria. Wherever you go in country Victoria, both municipal associations and ordinary citizens and townspeople speak very well of the way in which Olive continually travelled around country Victoria not only to hear what people had to say but also to take those issues back to government. I would like to place on record her contribution in that regard.

Last but not least I have been, for a brief time, with Senator Tierney on the employment, education and training committee. I also observed that Olive was a great contributor on that committee. She ran the legislation committee with great skill and, as other people from my side of the chamber have remarked, was always an extremely fair chairman. I, too, would like to extend my sympathy to her family, her friends and her staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —Olive Zakharov has left this chamber with many friends and no enemies. That is not a claim that many of us will be able to make when we leave this chamber. She set another distinction, of course—she was born in the Melbourne suburb of Kew. I think Gough Whitlam was also born there some 13 years earlier.

PARA.TAB: I had a long association with Olive in terms of Senate campaigns which I might mention in a moment. But if there were two outstanding qualities that summed up Olive Zakharov, one was loyalty and the second one was courage. Olive was loyal to the Labor Party to the extreme and loyal to the members of the Labor Party who thought the same way as she did. I never once knew Olive to waver when it came to loyalty to her party, to her faction or to her friends. When it comes to courage, she sometimes took up some rather unpopular causes out in the community and in this chamber and she never wavered. I saw Olive in action in the caucus, in the parliament and in party fora and never once did I see her not support the principles that she had held for a lifetime.

I most fondly remember Olive as one of the great advocates of a separate Senate campaign. We are all used to general elections in which issues of the House of Representatives dominate, but Olive always battled on with the car stickers, the badges and the badgering of me to get out to meetings. She always said that it could make a difference. It did once. In 1993 everyone—including her own faction, her own party and even me on occasions, I have to admit—gave up on the third position that she could not win. Olive came home and proved us all wrong. I must say how delighted we were that she had proved us wrong. She had won from No. 3 on the first occasion she stood, because there was a double dissolution in which she went to No. 5. She finished her political career with really the only time Labor has won the third position in that sort of a contest in Victoria since the 1940s.

Olive was also a resident of Port Melbourne and Port Melbourne has lost a great patron. But I hope many of the local issues that she pursued will continue to be pursued by everyone in this chamber. It is true that we were in different factions of the Labor Party, but I can honestly say that in the 12 years she was in Canberra she was an ornament to the Labor Party and an ornament to her own beliefs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in paying tribute to the late Senator Olive Zakharov. I did not know Olive very well in a political sense in this place but I had the opportunity to work with her on a number of committees. Also, in the early days that I was here we lived in the same neighbourhood in Canberra and I had the good opportunity occasionally to share a Comcar with her of an evening going home. I think it was very indicative that usually the first conversation that Senator Zakharov made with you was an inquiry about your family. It was always very personal. I found Senator Zakharov to be a genuine and compassionate conversationalist.

PARA.TAB: The people that will probably almost miss her the most are the Comcar drivers. In the past three weeks on just about every occasion that I have got into a Comcar the driver has made an inquiry of me as to whether I knew anything relating to Senator Zakharov's health. Like Senator Coates, many of those drivers are going to dearly miss Senator Zakharov.

In the area of parliamentary committees, again I had the good fortune to work with Senator Zakharov, particularly in the area that affected people with disabilities or the homeless. In both of those areas I know that Senator Zakharov was always their champion.

From an electorate point of view, I am well aware, as I am sure Senator Collins would be, that Senator Zakharov took a particular interest in parts of the Northern Territory and particularly the interests and the causes of Aborigines. She certainly had a close affinity with the many Aborigines who lived in Jabiru in the Kakadu region. Whether it was a matter of resources, environment or Aboriginal social issues, Senator Zakharov took the time to go and talk to those constituents in the Northern Territory and to find out the real issues and how they affected them. I am sure that then she reflected exactly what they had said and their conversations in the work that she participated in here in this parliament. I certainly would like to pass my condolences to any of those who shared Senator Zakharov's love.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of this motion. One thing that probably is becoming increasingly rare in politics in this day and age is to find a person as idealistic as Olive Zakharov was. She really was an idealist who combined her strong beliefs with a genuine commitment to political activism and sheer hard work.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that a lot of her political beliefs were shaped by her own life experiences, certainly her sense of justice and fairness, which she spoke of to so many of us for so long. I think that when she stood up in the Senate chamber, when she stood up in Senate committees, when she talked in the party caucus, when she spoke in faction meetings and talked about issues such as the position of single-parent families in our community she could do it from a personal perspective and her commitment to women's issues. She could do it as someone who had really been there.

When she stood up for people in need of social and community services Olive Zakharov really knew what she was talking about. When she defended an individual's right to education, again she was someone who had been there. She was someone who knew what it was like to battle to gain the qualifications to allow a person to really get ahead in life. Olive Zakharov was an extraordinarily committed member of the Labor Party. She really did believe that the quality of a society should be judged on the position that the least empowered people in that society found themselves in. She believed that those people really did deserve a strong voice in the Labor Party and a strong voice in parliament. I believe she gave them that voice. Yes, she was a gentle person, as so many have said, but I think she was a very determined and very persuasive person also. She really did take the issues on and argue them out, and she knew the importance of these issues to ordinary Australians.

When I came into the parliament in 1989, I was on the community affairs committee with Olive. We were inquiring at that time into employment and accommodation issues for people with disabilities. My own background before going into politics full time was working with disabled people. I believe she really did have an extraordinary understanding of issues relating to people with disabilities, and she showed it time and time again.

In relation to my subsequent roles in the chamber, firstly as one of the whips and then as Manager of Government Business, I appreciated the fact—as did, I am sure, all my colleagues, including the whips from the government side—that whenever Olive was asked to undertake a job on behalf of the government, whether it be speaking in a debate or serving on a committee, she always did it and she always did it well. I think we owe her a great debt of gratitude for that.

She was genuinely a great loyalist to the government, a great loyalist to the Labor Party and, as a couple of speakers have said, a great loyalist to the left of the party. I appreciate that she was standing in what is perhaps a much smaller part of the left wing corner of the chamber than the one where Senator Childs is—and I got that in quickly, Senator Ray—but she was a loyalist to her faction and a very important contributor to the left of the Labor Party, not only in the forum of the federal parliament but elsewhere, and we really appreciated that. As the minister for the environment, I noticed that she really did have a great interest in environmental issues. She had a genuine dedication to the protection of the Australian environment and the global environment, and I appreciated her support at that level and also at a factional and party level.

As has been said by many, Olive Zakharov obviously did not have an easy life at times. She made tireless efforts over many years to strengthen the social fabric of Australia. She did it through her advocacy of causes, many of which were not necessarily the most popular at all times. She provided all senators with a very fine example of what we are elected to this place to do. I want to join with all those other senators who have placed on record their great appreciation for an extraordinarily worthwhile life and to express my most sincere condolences to her family and to her friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly in support of the motion of condolence, I would like to say that I have learned new aspects of the person who was Olive Zakharov in the past few hours. None of the anecdotes have actually surprised me; they have served to confirm the person that I met in this place.

PARA.TAB: During almost all of the time I have been here, most of the time I spent in the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has been spent in the company of Olive Zakharov. I was fortunate to travel to many parts of Australia in her company. She was a wonderful travelling companion because she was able to express a great general knowledge. She was able to provide an interesting perspective on almost any topic you would care to raise, and she was willing to contribute to the finding out of a little more than that which the committee was empowered to do at the time.

Whilst travelling from one hearing to another we spent many hours having serious and earnest conversations about many aspects of international and local politics.
