We also had some light hearted exchanges over late meals that were far from family and home. As many speakers have confirmed, her family was often at the forefront of her conversations and she often inquired about our families, our welfare, what we were doing, why we were doing it and what our aspirations were. They were well intentioned and well appreciated inquiries.

Olive was not one to stand on ceremony in any fashion. I recall one anecdote that particularly reminds me of what Olive was about. It occurred when we were having hearings for the inquiry into open learning in Australia. The committee was exploring the thresholds of new technology, as some senators would appreciate. We were setting up in a particular place—and it does not matter where we were—and there was a video link between two TAFE campuses.

As usual, the committee was undergoing a little bit of preening, hair combing and adjustment while waiting to go ahead. I glanced at Olive and then glanced at the monitor. I noticed that her jacket was on the chair behind her and it gave a strange effect. I quietly said to Olive, `Perhaps you would like to move your jacket from the chair because the balance is not right and the jacket is inappropriate.' As soon as I had said it I knew I had said the wrong thing. This was entirely inappropriate. Olive's response was, `Don't worry about that, Robert. Provided Hansard can hear the questions it will be alright.' Typical no nonsense Olive.

I do not think she would mind me reminding the Senate that she had a particular speech pattern which included a nervous chuckle at the end of her statements. It occurred when she was being particularly determined, whether she was questioning somebody in a determined manner as part of her committee duties or whether she felt the need to press her position a little more strongly in deciding what should be contained in a committee report. I recall that particular speech pattern. I remind senators that when that came from Olive Zakharov it was a warning. It meant that she was determined and trying politely and without rancour to pursue her point of view. To me that was Olive. She was quietly and politely determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). In doing so, I also endorse the remarks made by the previous speakers. This morning when I came into my office there were a couple of messages from Senator Zakharov's staff. The information they forwarded to me was a message from the family and a message from Olive's daughter which I said I would undertake to read into Hansard. I am sure that if they could listen to the debate they would understand that the comments made by everyone more than cover the comments made in the message I received. The family comment is from Jeannie, Martin, Robin and grandson Tomas. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Many ordinary individuals have been in touch to speak of Olive. Many personal letters and cards have been received from people whose lives she has touched and whom she has helped—students, constituents, the unemployed, women.
Olive was committed to international peace, the environment, legal reform, HIV/AIDS education and support for sufferers—the list is endless.
She never became cynical, but kept fighting for what she believed in, and encouraged those around her to have the same world view.
Olive's commitment to peace and justice issues started within the community long before she entered the Senate, and continued in her representation of those issues in public office.
Her long term commitment to social justice has touched the lives of people throughout Australia.
She was hardworking and unassuming, and she was not ambitious for herself but for the causes and issues that she represented.
She was the sole female government representative from Victoria.
That was a comment from her children—Jeannie, Martin, Robin—and her grandson Tomas. I have a letter from her daughter, Jeannie Zakharov, which reads:
My mother kept a strong and optimistic commitment to social justice and to the rights and welfare of ordinary Australians throughout her life.
She was someone who cared passionately, always, about alleviating social ills. More importantly, she worked hard to alleviate those ills. She was never an armchair activist.

Despite a lifetime of political activity, which can blunt and degrade the ideals and values of some who follow that path, she remained a moral beacon, firmly committed to lifelong ideals, always compassionate, always positive.

We, her family have received so many expressions of condolence. What has touched me the most has been the letters from individuals who she had helped over the years. Her goodness and generosity touched many many lives.

She will be painfully missed by her family, and the many other people who loved her dearly. Society is the poorer for her death, too, as it always is, and will be, when we lose someone of her quality.

This morning when I arrived at the office very early the first person that came in was one of the attendants called Terry. He said, `Senator, I just want to pass on our condolences from all the attendants, the drivers and the other people within the parliament. She was a great lady and we loved her.'

PARA.TAB: Finally, I might also mention that we rang her office. The way in which her staff held her in such high esteem is clearly shown by this comment. My secretary was talking to one of the staff members who was very upset with the passing of Olive and she was crying. She said that she wanted someone to bring Olive back.

TALK.START.PARA: —The life, the works and the sudden passing of Senator Zakharov give us all cause to consider how frail our existence is. One of the great things about Olive Zakharov was that she had a unique opportunity, which we in this place at least have the chance to share, of putting into practice her principles and her beliefs.

PARA.TAB: I had the benefit of sharing five years with Olive Zakharov on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I note that Senator Colston is seeking the call on the other side. I am sure he will mention her membership of that committee.

I would just like to say this about Senator Zakharov: although we came from opposite ends of the spectrum, when we were working on that committee you knew that everything she said and everything she did was governed by commitment to the dignity and the rights of the individual. Her work on that committee has been invaluable. Her sharpness of mind, which was indeed considerable, aided the work of the committee. Thousands of Australians have benefited from Senator Zakharov standing up for their rights in the forum of that committee.

I cannot comment on all the other areas of Senator Zakharov's concern. I do not have first-hand knowledge of them. But I think the important thing is this: Senator Zakharov was somebody who genuinely translated beliefs and principles into action. As a result of her work, other Australians are the better. In the brief time that we all have here, that is something to which all honourable senators probably aspire. Many perhaps will not do it as well as Senator Zakharov.

It is appropriate to say to her family and her friends not just that we extend to them our condolences, which we certainly do—and I shall certainly miss Senator Zakharov's contributions, wit and keenness of mind—but also that we thank them for letting us have Senator Zakharov's company and her contributions. This parliament, this Senate and—I think this is something that Senator Zakharov would appreciate—the people are the better for what she has done. We are all grateful and we will miss her immensely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself also with the condolence motion moved today. I am not sure when I first met Olive, both of us having been around the Labor Party for over 20 years now, but I certainly recall meeting her in 1983 when we both were standing as Senate candidates, she successfully and me unsuccessfully. I knew her when I worked on the staff of a member of the other house and from her commitment to the status of women committee. I really started to get to know Olive when I was here briefly in 1987, but learnt to know her and learnt to love her on my return in 1990 when I shared a lot of committees with her. Her committee work has been alluded to previously.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I learnt about Olive was her clear vision of what was right and what was wrong. She was never afraid to take a stance on a position nor to justify it, but she always tempered that with respect for others who hold a different point of view. She would argue the point but never the person. Working with her gave me the privilege of knowing a truly loyal and humble person who sought for herself nothing, but sought everything for her fellow human being.

In this place—a place with considerable egos—there are a number who play the press gallery and there are some who measure their performances by the column inches they receive. This was never the case with Olive. Despite not being a media junkie, she was known and respected by a very diverse range of people. Since her accident, every time I have travelled in a Comcar, the driver has asked, `How is Senator Zakharov?' and said `We all love her.' The same is true of the people working in the dining rooms and everywhere else. The Comcar drivers said that it did not matter what time of the day or night she hopped into a car or what sort of a day she had had—it could have been one of those absolutely horrible days when all we do in here is fight and scratch and spit and scream at one another—Olive would be polite and courteous. She never took her bad days out on them.

I represented Minister Carmen Lawrence at a nursing home opening in Temora 10 days ago. The architects involved in the construction of this building were from Victoria. One of the principals of the firm was there at the opening and, as soon as he got an opportunity, he inquired after Olive's condition. It transpires that his firm had been involved in the construction of a number of nursing homes throughout a very wide area of Victoria. From conversations that he had had with Olive at so many of the openings that she attended, he was very much aware of her commitment to aged care and her commitment to the care of people with disabilities. He asked me to pass on to her family and to her staff his thoughts and best wishes, which I have certainly done.

It was Olive to whom my staff turned in December 1993 when my husband suddenly died. I will never be fully aware of the support and care that she gave to them, but I know that they are very upset today. Her staff are also very special people. They ran Olive's office in a manner which epitomised her attitude to life and her caring for so many people, including us. Her support to me and my staff during that time can never be repaid. For that, we shall be eternally grateful. All I can do today is to publicly say, `Thank you, Olive.'

I shall also never forget my birthday last year, the first one after Peter's death. I thought it was going to be a sad and lonely day. I will never forget receiving a phone call from Olive asking whether she could have an appointment to see me, as her committee chair, in her office at 10 o'clock that morning. It was a little strange. I did not think much of it, but I said that I would go there later that morning.

Earlier that morning, I got a hint that something was a bit funny, but assumed that my caucus sisters and staff were probably planning a bit of a surprise. No-one can imagine my surprise when I walked into her office to find it all decorated with balloons and signs—the whole bit—with nearly half the members of the caucus, caucus committee staff as well as my two stepdaughters and three grandchildren there. Olive was more than happy to have her office disrupted to enable people to support me. That was typical of Olive. That gesture meant a lot to me. She helped turn what would have been a sad and lonely day into one I shall never forget. I know that Vicki, Helen and the three grandchildren would want to pass on to Olive's family and her staff their thanks for being able to share that day.

Olive brought to this place a great depth of knowledge of the university of life. She had academic qualifications, but she had also experienced life to the fullest, and not necessarily the nicest sides of life. That knowledge, commonsense and experience that she brought here are things that we and the general community should be grateful for, because it tempered her approach to legislation and brought to it a commonsense approach.
There are two quotes in her maiden speech which I think epitomise what Olive stood for. The first is her quote of the great English socialist RH Tawney:
Freedom, to be complete, must carry with it not merely the absence of repression, but also the opportunity of self-organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: To all those small organisations and her support for them, Olive epitomised and lived that piece.

PARA.TAB: She also said that her favourite piece of Shakespeare was in Hamlet, which she paraphrased. It epitomised her personal philosophy. It was this:

SPEECH.PARA: To thine own self be true,
And it must follow, as the night the day,
Thou canst not then be false to any man.
She added to this the word `woman'. Olive, you were true to yourself. You were never false to anybody. No-one can ask more than that.

PARA.TAB: My thoughts are with her children—Robin, Martin and Jeannie—her sister and other family members and especially to Thomas, her grandson, because he will never grow up to know her and see her influence. My thoughts are also with Olive's staff, who are as loving and caring to everybody as she was. We have all lost a very true friend, and the world is a little poorer for her passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). It is not my practice to speak at length in condolence motions. Today I shall be extremely brief. My brevity should not be regarded as an indication that I do not feel devastated by Olive's passing. In fact, the opposite is the case.

PARA.TAB: Olive was a dear friend of my wife and of mine. Indeed, she was loved by many thousands of people who had the privilege of knowing her warmth and sincerity. I will miss Olive deeply. I regret that I did not have the opportunity to say goodbye. She will remain in my memory for the remainder of my life.

In extending my condolences to Olive's family, I mention I had the pleasure of meeting Olive's son and one of her daughters when I led a parliamentary delegation to the United Kingdom and Austria. Both were working overseas. Olive took the opportunity of seeing Jeannie in the UK and Martin in Austria. I cannot recall meeting Robin, but Olive spoke warmly about all her family, often when we were having dinner together in Parliament House. This must be a distressing time for all members of Olive's family. It may ease their pain a little to be aware that their distress is shared by so many who loved her.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to associate myself with this condolence motion. I pass on my condolences to Olive's family, friends and colleagues. You would have to say, `What would a Liberal Party senator from Tasmania have in common with a left Labor Party senator from Victoria?' It is a lot more than I thought after spending two years with Olive on the employment, education and training committee and working through one particular report called Come in Cinderella on adult education. That is where I think she gained the thoughts about looking at correctional facilities and the uses of education there. There was also the youth unemployment inquiry with the report called Wanted: our future.

PARA.TAB: A couple of anecdotes come to mind. A lot has been said here today about what Comcar thought about Olive. I remember staying at the Grosvenor Hotel in Adelaide before going north to Gawler to take evidence on youth unemployment. It was the day Comcar switched over the computers. I can remember that after waiting two hours outside of the Grosvenor Hotel with Olive she had some wonderful thoughts about Comcar!

I have heard a lot of people talk today about Olive's independence. I remember talking to her many times and she told me that it was only when she came to this place that she started wearing dresses. She had an office next to mine, which I remember well, particularly in those years when her staff member had the young child.

A lot has been said today about Olive. She has been claimed by the left wing of the Labor party and she has been claimed by the Labor Party. But Olive was part of the Senate and she should be claimed by all of us. We are all a little sadder and a little worse off for her passing. I pass on my condolences to her family and friends.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to say a few things about Olive Zakharov. To describe her as a sincere person is one thing, but I think we need to describe her as a lot more. `A sincere, relentless battler for the powerless and the dispossessed'is something that everyone has said in one way or another during the course of the last two hours on this condolence motion.

PARA.TAB: She was a fighter for the dignity of the individual. She was a fighter for and defender of diversity and she was a fighter for the protection of heritage. All of those issues she came to, not just with an understanding drawn out of her professional understanding and learning, but because of the experiences she had in life. She understood when she spoke about the need to protect diversity and to protect the dignity of individuals. She had suffered and experienced it in her personal life and she had the courage to front it there and in her public life, and to front it in a way that quite often meant she was a pioneer in some of the issues she pursued.

She was driven by that idealism and integrity. As some speakers have mentioned, the sense of humour also came out from time to time. You knew she was probably at her toughest when she did, as Senator Bell said, have that chuckle.

I think the one thing that permeates all the contributions made about Olive and permeated Olive's whole life here was that she never lost that contact with individuals in the community, community organisations and their causes. In fact, the last day of her consciousness epitomises her life and her battles. I actually met her on that Sunday morning. Brian Howe and I had launched the second stage of the citizenship campaign at Station Pier. Olive came up at the end. She was puffing and a bit hot and flustered and I said, `What's wrong?' She said, `I have just run from home. I don't live too far away. I heard on the news that you were here and we have got to do something to protect the seamen's union building. We have to protect this precinct.' She had obviously just run from home to there to try to achieve some publicity for it. That is what she said she wanted to do. She wanted to save the building. She wanted to protect the history of that site and she went on to lobby the media on that very same morning of the day she was run over.

That building, in a sense, does represent the sorts of things Olive fought for all the way through. It represents the struggle of workers and their families and it represents her commitment to heritage issues. It also reflects the local and international coming together in that commitment she showed on the last morning. We have been told about the gay and lesbian network function she went to in the afternoon.

I suppose one of my earliest memories of her was of her performance, her contribution and her commitment—in fact, I found it inspirational—on the issue of Kakadu. She made endless speeches in here and she travelled the country with respect to the spiritual rights of the Jawoyn people and the rights of indigenous Australians. If I could remember once when I saw Olive frustrated and angry, it was during that battle. I think very few in this place and the other place understood to the extent that she did the spiritual rights of indigenous Australians.

It was long before the cabinet took on the decision to protect the site at Kakadu, the Jawoyn site at Coronation Hill, that she had travelled the country and made speeches. Whilst a lone battler for a while, she just took on that cause no matter what the odds. I must say I was gratified a few years later when I went to Kakadu to meet with the elders and they had great respect and regard for her and remembered her. I think in the same way as they remember her, many others in society will too. I would like to express my condolences to her family, staff and friends on what we see as the passing of a very special person.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great sense of sadness and loss that I rise today to support this motion of condolence for Senator Zakharov. People have talked today about her background and her concern about people being deprived, denied civil liberties, denied the opportunity to lead a life where at least the necessities were available to all and her response to that. I guess one could say, `How could anyone respond in another way?'

PARA.TAB: I think all of us here in this place know that others scarred by such an upbringing, scarred by such an experience, have sought to escape it by uplifting themselves and taking refuge in riches and power and having no concern for those they left behind. But that was not Olive's position. She fought not only to uplift herself by way of education, by way of activity, by way of doing things but also to take the rest of the community with her. I believe that is the measure of Olive Zakharov. She fought against all those elements for so long.

People have talked about her sense of loyalty to people within her political party and to organisations in which she was active. I believe her first loyalty was to the people out there in the community who were unable to help themselves, who did not help themselves and who needed her work and her activity very badly and were given it in great measure. As a result of using organisations as a tool—organisations like the peace movement, the Labor Party, the Labor government, the parliament itself—and working with other people to achieve the goals that she saw as important, she did have that sort of loyalty, she did have that sort of compassion for others, and she did have a great deal of concern about the way in which she was active in helping those people.

Olive has without a doubt left the world a better place than it was when she came into it. I would like to extend my condolences to her family and friends and to say that, though she has left this world, her image of being a very good person, a very wonderful person, will never leave my memory—a memory that I will always cherish.

TALK.START.PARA: —At varying times in the future we who are present here will have the worth of our lives assessed by our Senate peers, whether by this or coming generations. Let us hope we fare as well as Olive has today.

—I rise to speak very briefly on this motion of condolence. As the newest senator in this place, I am not able to speak of a lifetime or of many years of association with Senator Zakharov. But in the short time I have been here I can certainly recognise all of the qualities of Senator Zakharov that so many have spoken about here today.

PARA.TAB: When new members of parliament arrive, they experience a feeling of confusion and are a bit lost for a while as they come to grips with the procedures of the committees and the chambers. I recall being asked very early by the whip what committees I wanted to go on. I was also told, `Don't hold your breath that you will get on the ones that you select.' But I was indeed fortunate to be appointed as a member of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. It was there that I very quickly recognised all of those qualities of patience, tolerance, commitment, knowledge and understanding that characterised Senator Zakharov.

I particularly appreciated the fact that I was able to have a cup of coffee with Senator Zakharov after a committee meeting while she explained various procedures as to how the system worked. She was certainly the member of this chamber I had the most dealings with when I first arrived, and I learned a heck of a lot from her.

I recall, as Senator Bell has mentioned, our travels around the country last year in the open learning inquiry. I know that Senator Bell will recall our visit to the Yuendumu Aboriginal station. It did not get as much publicity as a visit a week earlier by another member of parliament, but it was certainly a most worthwhile visit. It was the first opportunity that I ever had of visiting an Aboriginal settlement. I certainly recall Senator Zakharov's commitment to and enthusiasm for improving the educational opportunities of the Aboriginal people at that location and elsewhere.

While I cannot speak necessarily about all of the many things that Senator Zakharov did throughout her life and her contribution to this parliament—others have done that so eloquently today—what I will miss is the fact that I will not have the advice and assistance in the future that I have had in the short time I have been here. It will certainly stand me, and I know other senators, in good stead for many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The passing of a dear and valued colleague always raises in one's mind the question of mortality in general and one's own mortality in particular. I have several thoughts in relation to the passing of Olive Zakharov. The first is that—and I am reflecting here on what Senator Bryant Burns has just said—each generation essentially represents an extremely thin slice of the totality of humanity, and each individual an even smaller slice than that.

PARA.TAB: I suppose when one looks at the shortness of a human life, one looks at whether a person has utilised the society as it is, exploited the society as it is and passed on perhaps leaving the world in a poorer shape—whether one has been a freeloader—or whether one has, indeed, made an incremental improvement so that the next generation has a marginally better circumstance than the one into which that person was born. I think, in that respect, one must say that Olive Zakharov was very true to her principles and was very consistent. She showed a very high level of integrity and did everything that she possibly could to ensure that the world that she left behind would be a marginally better world than the world into which she was born and, in that, she succeeded.

The second thought that arises in my mind is that, throughout the course of a life, one is born, one lives and one dies. We all go through those phases. In learning how we might approach life, we are often given lessons by our elders. I am reminded of the following words that Kipling wrote to his young son:

SPEECH.PARA: If you can keep your head when all about you
Are losing theirs and blaming it on you,
If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you,
But make allowance for their doubting too—

In the hurly-burly of this chamber, with the way in which Olive Zakharov conducted herself, I think she totally fulfilled the injunction which Kipling laid as one of those injunctions for his son and which, of course, in a day of sexual equality, one would write in somewhat different terms. In those two respects, Olive Zakharov will be indeed extremely missed by this chamber and, of course, by her friends. I join with all the others who have spoken in extending my condolences to her family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments which have already been made and to add briefly to them. One of the best ways of getting to know fellow senators is to travel with them on delegations or on committee inquiries. I had the privilege of travelling to Europe with Senator Zakharov in July 1991, to which Senator Colston has already alluded. She was a very good travelling companion, actively involved at all times with a clear idea of what she wanted to achieve and, I believe, generally achieving it. She provided a much needed countervailing influence to the inevitable and, I suppose, necessary trade and economic focus that most of our delegations take when travelling. Senator Zakharov insisted on broadening this view to include social and cultural concerns. She was recently selected to be part of a delegation which I will be leading to Canada and the United States in April. Already in the meetings that we have had, the preparatory ones that she was able to attend, she had influenced the delegates' focus again to broaden and human

SPEECH.PARA: ise it. I also enjoyed the privilege of serving on committees with Senator Zakharov, most recently on the Joint House Committee and a subcommittee that we set up to oversee the new art acquisition program, which she was very keen on. Here also she was a person of firmly held and strongly expressed convictions, not afraid to stand out alone against strong opposition.

PARA.TAB: In all of these associations, I found her to be not only honest and principled, as everybody has already attested to, but also refreshingly young and modern in her outlook, despite her years. She was broad-minded and flexible, not easily shocked or disturbed by new or radical ideas or concepts. But the characteristic which above all set her apart from others was her genuine humility. She was devoid of the ego which drives so many—dare I say, particularly in this place. She was proud of her humble background and this, together with some traumatic periods in her life which others have alluded to, was reflected in the way that she was able to empathise so effectively with people in difficulty.

The Senate is the worse for her passing. I add my condolences to those being sent to her children, Martin, Jeannie and Robin—two of whom I met in Europe when we were there—to other relatives and friends, and to her staff who have been loyal to her as she was to them. I ask honourable senators to stand in silence to acknowledge the passing of Alice Olive Zakharov and to remember the contribution which she made to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That, as a mark of respect to the memory of the late Senator Alice Olive Zakharov, the Senate do now adjourn.
